data.text:
Dear friends of Hotel Villa Schuler,

If you have ever attended an event at our wonderful Teatro Antico you will never forget this! The Greeks, who created this marvellous place around the 3rd century BC, knew a lot about acoustics and they knew exactly where to place their venues to create the greatest impact in interaction with the surrounding nature. And the Romans, who remodelled the ancient theatre 500 years later, also had a good feel for the drama of a place.

Experiencing an event in this theatre with its great accustics and its views to the see and Mt. Etna is unique. But Taormina also has other very charming places and opportunities to experience a cultural evening. There is for example the small and refined Nazarena Theater, which hosts the much-loved performances of the Italian Opera, or the ancient roman Odeon, which is the setting for selected chamber concerts during the summer period, or the lovely baroque Church Santa Caterina, where the “Taormina Classics” concerts enrich the autumn in Taormina, and many other beautiful venues, so that you can enrich your stay in Taormina experiencing unforgettable cultural events.

This is why we are constantly looking for the best events that Taormina and near places in Sicily have to offer, which is still a little difficult at the beginning of the year. Many events of the season 2024 are not yet firmly planned or have yet to be confirmed. However, we will keep you up to date and will publish all interesting events on this page.

Castello di Taormina – above Madonna della Rocca, Taormina

During the months of July and August, the Arab-Norman Castle of Taormina, lately reopened to the public, will extend its visiting hours with an atmospheric evening opening. On Saturdays, the current hours that run from 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. will thus be extended until midnight. The Castle is a symbol of the beauty of Taormina with four panoramas and breathtaking views. The first fortified construction probably dates back to the Byzantine age, representing for a long time one of the defense outposts in the war against the Arabs. From August 908 to 969 Taormina was subjected to three Saracen invasions, the last one, from 964 to 969, ended with a capitulation, and the territory of the island was divided into five administrative units: Taormina, Palermo, Messina , Syracuse and Trapani. The Normans liberated Taormina and besieged the castle in 1079. In 1134 the town was subjected to the monastery of San Salvatore della Placa near Francavilla di Sicilia. During the rule of Frederick II of Swabia the fortress was entrusted to a noble castellan.

Three champions born a quarter of a century apart, linked by a red thread that is not only football-related, but also poetic and social: Sivori enchanted Argentina in the 1950s, at the height of the economic boom; Maradona, El pibe de oro, the greatest ever, became the idol of a people emerging from the recession and General Videla’s dictatorship in the 1980s; and finally Messi, the enfant prodige of contemporary football, the national hero of an Argentina that has reached the roof of the world since the default. by and with Federico Buffa, Alessandro Nidi (piano) and Mascia Foschi (singer).

Palazzo Ciampoli – Taormina

From Tauromenion to Tauromenium. The Invisible City between History and Archaeology, re-read by a team of archaeologists cross-referencing documents and artifacts. 3D digital reconstructions restore the vision of a scenic urban center designed to look out to sea and be admired from miles away. From the Taormina of the Greeks (Tauromenion) to that of Roman times (Tauromenium). Captured in the time span of its greatest splendor – from the 3rd century B.C. and up to II A.D. – the city nestled on the flanks of Mount Taurus and with an imposing scenic layout, where every monument was conceived by the Greeks to look at the sea – and from the sea to be admired – will be the protagonist of the archaeological and multimedia exhibition.

Daily from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. Tickets at the box office: full 5 euros, reduced 2,50 euros

Excerpts from the opera Cavalleria Rusticana by Pietro Mascagni, an evocative interpretation of Pietro Mascagni’s timeless masterpiece, performed live and open air in the garden of the theatre by outstanding artists, accompanied by equally virtuos pianists. Set in a rustic Sicilian village, this opera tells a compelling story of love, betrayal and revenge, exploring the depths of human emotion against the backdrop of rural Italy. At the centre of the story is the overwhelming passion between Turiddu, a young soldier, and Lola, the wife of the carter Alfio. Their illicit affair triggers a series of events that lead to heartbreak and tragedy. Art director Silvia Di Falco.

The association, founded in 2010 from an idea of Titti Mazza, aims to promote educational as well as artistic and cultural initiatives in a path of integration of able-bodied and differently abled individuals within the social fabric. The Association’s Theater Workshop, led by director Fabio La Rosa, is a project that realizes and carries out goals that are difficult to achieve in everyday situations; on stage, however, integration occurs naturally.

Puccini Celebration: Tosca – La Boheme – Madame Butterfly suites. Sumptuous celebration of the 100th anniversary of the death of the composer of love, Giacomo Puccini, in the magnificence of Taormina’s Teatro. A musical triptych event with excerpts from three cornerstone operas of Puccini’s production. Among the stars of the event will be the internationally renowned pianist Lola Astanova, who for the occasion will perform, as premieres, several fantasias for solo piano inspired by the composer from Lucca. The parade of stars includes tenor Walter Fraccaro, baritone Carlos Almaguer, the Bellini Symphony Orchestra and the Sicilian Opera Chorus. A production of the Festival Lirico dei Teatri di Pietra in collaboration with the Naxos Taormina Archaeological Park.
